author: popef
content: But is there no rate limiting on requesting blob transactions?

author: savid
content: doesn't seem so. can almost saturate a nodes 1gpbs upload with a > 500kb payload. nethermind does seem to not return a response if a payload would be > ~1MB

author: popef
content: I think it's better to ensure before doing that.

author: savid
content: if there are no limits and the measurements are reasonably accurate, is this data worth collecting?

author: popef
content: But I would say I would not consider it as available bandwidth either measured on the CL or the EL because it's very likely that the node will allocate some bandwidth to serve the RPC request even if it has no bandwidth available as I mentioned in https://ethresear.ch/t/bandwidth-availability-in-ethereum-regional-differences-and-network-impacts/21138/4?u=pop

author: popef
content: How do you know it's accurate?

author: savid
content: i'd test against way more nodes that i know the max upload of. If i can't get a close measurement of that nodes max upload over a period of time, i'd probably say that its not reasonably accurate.

author: popef
content: I think that's good test. But I think the most interesting and essential one is maybe you can try running a node and make sure it uses all of your bandwidth and try to measure the available bandwidth, if what you measured is close to zero, I would say it's quite accurate.

author: savid
content: i've done that in limited tests, measuring ~950mbs of a node with a 1gpbs max upload. Also tested a couple residential nodes that i know the max upload and gotten measurements fairly close to the max upload speeds.

author: savid
content:
>  When you send an RPC call, it will probably reduce the bandwidth used by the clients to 40Mbps and use another 10Mbps to serve your RPC call.
Are you saying clients actively limit bandwidth, or that bandwidth would be in use by other peers of that node?

author: popef
content:
> measuring ~950mbs of a node with a 1gpbs max upload
I'm not surprised with that number if your node is not busy. What I'm curious more is when the node bandwidth has been saturated.

author: popef
content: I don't quite understand your question. It's already said in the quote that another 10Mbps is used to serve your RPC call.

author: savid
content:
Yeah, so what I'm suggesting is collect a dataset of the max bandwidth of nodes across the network.

Then get some local measurements of the bandwidth usage of typical EL/CL's with default number of peers and range of upload speeds. Also taking into account; time into the slot, number of blobs, etc.

From there you can estimate the available bandwidth.

author: popef
content: Alright, how can you get the max bandwidth of nodes?
